Posts.Content: Hello, I posted a question regarding flaxseed previously but did not get a large response. My girlfriend told me about flaxseed and its preventative effects on breast cancer according to a few medical studies. I did my own research and found that for cancer, the part of the flaxseed that is important are the lignans and not the oil component. I did most of my research on the web at the National Library of Medicine website (www.pubmed.com). You can type in any key words such as "flaxseed lignans cancer" and you will see a considerable list of medical studies. Apparently flaxseed has been known for a while but studies show that it is the Lignan component and not the oils that seem to be effective as an aniti-tumor agent. The studies seem very promising and I am taking flaxseed lignans. I must say that it is early but I do feel better with more energy- I believe that this can have great potential from the science behind it. Studies are being done on its effectiveness on other hormone related cancers as well. Some of the studies I have listed below. I hope this helps. I would like to know your thoughts. ~selena Thompson LU. Experimental studies on lignans and cancer. Baillieres Clin Endocrin Metab. 12:691-705, 1998. Thompson LU, et al. Flaxseed and its lignan and oil components reduce mammary tumor growth at a late stage of carcinogenesis. Carcinogenesis 1996 Jun; 17(6):1373- Serraino M, et al. The effect of flaxseed supplementation on early risk markers for mammary carcinogenesis. Cancer Letters. 60(1991) 135-142. Hirano T, et al. Antiproliferative activity of mammalian lignan derivatives against the human breast carcinoma cell line, ZR-75-1. Cancer Investigation 1990; 8(6): 595-602. Denmark-Wahnefried W, et al. Pilot study of dietary fat restriction and flaxseed supplementation in men with prostate cancer before surgery: exploring the effects on hormonal levels, prostate-specific antigen, and histopathologic features. Urology. 58:47-52, 2001. Haggans CJ, et al. Effect of flaxseed consumption on urinary estrogen metabolites in postmenopausal women. Nutrition and Cancer. 33:188-195, 1999. Tham DM, et al. Potential health benefits of dietary phytoestrogens: A review of the clinical, epidemiological, and mechanistic evidence. J Clin Endocrinol Metab. 83: 2223-2235, 1998.
Posts.Title: Flax seed oil and cottage cheese

Posts.Content: Hi, yes I have seen her research and advice. Though I think for what you are looking for, it is the flaxseed lignans that are the most important. This seems to have the most scientific research behind it and I am sure that the doctor would agree as well. The oils of the flaxseed have not been shown to have the potency on tumor cells as the lignans. This is according to the research I have conducted at the National Library of Medicine website. take care!
